column1: evaṃ saṃcintayanviṣṇumabhedenātmano dvija / tanmayatvamavāpyagrya mene cātmānamacyutam // visasmāra tathātmānaṃ nānyatkiñcidajānata / ahamevāvyayo 'nantaḥ paramātmetyacintayat // tasya tadbhāvanāyogātkṣīṇapāpasya vai kramāt / śuddhentaḥkaraṇe viṣṇustasthau jñānamayocyutaḥ //
column2: THUS meditating upon Viṣṇu, as identical with his own spirit, Prahlāda became as one with him, and finally regarded himself as the divinity he forgot entirely his own individuality, and was conscious of nothing else than his being the inexhaustible, eternal, supreme soul and in consequence of the efficacy of this conviction of identity, the imperishable Viṣṇu, whose essence is wisdom, became present in his heart, which was wholly purified from sin.

column1: yogaprabhāvātprahlāde jāte viṣṇumaye 'sure / calatyuragabandhais tair maitreya truṭitaṃ kṣaṇāt // bhrantagrāhagamaḥ sormiryayau kṣobhaṃ mahārṇavaḥ / cacāla ca mahī sarvā saśailavanakānanā // sa ca taṃ śailasaṃghātaṃ daityair nyastamathopari / utkṣipya tasmātsalilānniścakrāma mahāmatiḥ //
column2: As soon as, through the force of his contemplation, Prahlāda had become one with Viṣṇu, the bonds with which he was bound burst instantly asunder the ocean was violently uplifted and the monsters of the deep were alarmed earth with all her forests and mountains trembled and the prince, putting aside the rocks which the demons had piled Upon him, came forth from out the main.

column1: dṛṣṭvā ca sa jagadbhū6yo gaganādyupalakṣaṇam / prahlādosmīti sasmāra punarātmānamātmani // tuṣṭāva ca punardhāmānanādiṃ puruṣottamam / ekāgramatiravyagro yatavākvāyamānasaḥ //
column2: When he beheld the outer world again, and contemplated earth and heaven, he remembered who he was, and recognised himself to be Prahlāda and again he hymned Puruṣottama, who is without beginning or end his mind being steadily and undeviatingly addressed to the object of his prayers, and his speech, thoughts, and acts being firmly under control.

column1: prahlāda uvāca oṃnamaḥ paramārthāya sthūla sūkṣmakṣarākṣara / vyaktāvyaktakalātīta sakaleśa nicañjana // guṇāñjana guṇādhāra nirguṇātman guṇasthita / mūrtāmūrtamahāmūrte sūkṣmamūrte sphuṭāsphuṭa // karālasaumyarūpātmanvidyāvidyāmayācyuta / sadasadrūpasadbhāva sadasadbhāvabhāvana //
column2: “Om! glory to the end of all to thee, lord, who art subtile and substantial mutable and immutable perceptible and imperceptible divisible and indivisible indefinable and definable the subject of attributes, and void of attributes abiding in qualities, though they abide not in thee morphous and amorphous minute and vast visible and invisible hideousness and beauty ignorance and wisdom cause and effect existence and nonexistence comprehending all that is good and evil essence of perishable and imperishable elements asylum of undeveloped rudiments.

column1: nityānityaprapañcātmanniṣprapañcāmalāśrita / ekāneka namastubhyaṃ vāsudevādikāraṇa //
column2: Oh thou who art both one and many, Vāsudeva, first cause of all glory be unto thee.

column1: yaḥ sthūlasūkṣmaḥ prakaṭaḥ prakāśo yaḥ sarvabhūto na ca sarvabhūtaḥ / viśvaṃ yataścaitadaviśvaheto namostu tasmai puruṣottamāya // parāśara uvāca
column2: Oh thou who art large and small, manifest and hidden who art all beings, and art not all beings and from whom, although distinct from universal cause, the universe proceeds to thee, Puruṣottama, be all glory.”

column1: sasambhramas tam ālokya samutthāyākulākṣaram / namostu viṣṇavetyetavdyājahārāsa kṛddvija //
column2: Whilst with mind intent on Viṣṇu, he thus pronounced his praises, the divinity, clad in yellow robes, suddenly appeared before him.

column1: deva prapannārtihara prasādaṃ kuru keśava / avalokanadānena bhūyo māṃ pāvayācyuta // śrībhagavān uvāca kurvataste prasannohaṃ bhaktimavyabhicāriṇīm / yathābhilaṣito mattaḥ prahlāda vrīyatāṃ varaḥ // prahlāda uvāca nātha yonisahasreṣu yeṣu yeṣu vrajāmy aham / teṣu teṣvacyutābhaktiracyutāstu sadā tvayi //
column2: Startled at the sight, with hesitating speech Prahlāda pronounced repeated salutations to Viṣṇu, and said, “Oh thou who removest all worldly grief, Keśava, be propitious unto me again sanctify me, Achyuta, by thy sight.” The deity replied, “I am pleased with the faithful attachment thou hast shown to me demand from me, Prahlāda, whatever thou desirest.” Prahlāda replied, “In all the thousand births through which I may be doomed to pass, may my faith in thee, Achyuta, never know decay may passion, as fixed as that which the worldlyminded feel for sensual pleasures, ever animate my heart, always devoted unto thee.” Bhagavān answered, “Thou hast already devotion unto me, and ever shalt have it now choose some boon, whatever is in thy wish.” Prahlāda then said, “I have been hated, for that I assiduously proclaimed thy praise do thou, oh lord, pardon in my father this sin that he Bath committed.

column1: mayi dveṣānubandhobhūtsaṃstutāvudyate tava / matpitustatkṛtaṃ pāpaṃ deva tasya pramaśyatu // śastrāṇi pātitānyaṅge kṣipto yaccāgnisaṃhatau / daṃśitaścoragair dattaṃ yadviṣaṃ mama bhojane // baddhā samudre yatkṣipto yaccito 'smi śiloccayaiḥ / anyāni cāpyasādhūni yāni pitrā kṛtāti me // tvayi bhaktimato dveṣādaghaṃ tatsaṃbhavaṃ ca yat / tvatprasādātprabho sadyastena mucyatu me pitā //
column2: Weapons have been hurled against me I have been thrown into the flames I have been bitten by venomous snakes and poison has been mixed with my food I have been bound and cast into the sea and heavy rocks have been heaped upon me but all this, and whatever ill beside has been wrought against me whatever wickedness has been done to me, because I put my faith in thee all, through thy mercy, has been suffered by me unharmed and do thou therefore free my father from this iniquity.” To this application Viṣṇu replied, “All this shall be unto thee, through my favour but I give thee another boon demand it, son of the Asura.” Prahlāda answered and said, “All my desires, oh lord, have been fulfilled by the boon that thou hast granted, that my faith in thee shall never know decay.

column1: dharmārthakāmaiḥ kiṃ tasya muktistasya kare stitā / samastajagatāṃ mūle yasya bhaktiḥ sthirā tvayi // śrībhagavānuvāca yathā te niścalaṃ ceto mayi bhaktisamanvitam / tathā tvaṃ matprasādena nirvāṇamparamāpsyasi // śrīparāśara uvāca ityuktvāntardadhe viṣṇus tasya maitreya paśyataḥ / sa cāpi punarāgamya vavande caraṇau pituḥ //
column2: Wealth, virtue, love, are as nothing for even liberation is in his reach whose faith is firm in thee, root of the universal world.” Viṣṇu said, “Since thy heart is filled immovably with trust in me, thou shalt, through my blessing, attain freedom from existence.” Thus saying, Viṣṇu vanished from his sight and Prahlāda repaired to his father, and bowed down before him.

column1: taṃ pitā mūrdhnyupāghrāya pariṣvajya ca pīḍitam / jīvasītyāha vatseti bāṣpārdranayanodvija // prītimāṃścābhavattasminnanutāpī mahāsuraḥ / gurupitroścakāraivaṃ śuśrūṣāṃ so 'pi dharmatam //
column2: His father kissed him on the forehead, and embraced him, and shed tears, and said, “Dost thou live, my son?” And the great Asura repented of his former cruelty, and treated him with kindness and Prahlāda, fulfilling his duties like any other youth, continued diligent in the service of his preceptor and his father.

column1: pitaryuparatiṃ nīte narasiṃha svarūpiṇā / viṣṇunā so 'pi daityānāṃ maitreyābhūtpatistataḥ // tato rājyadyutiṃ prāpya karmaśuddhikarīṃ dvīja / putrapautrāṃś ca subahūn avāpyaiśvaryameva ca //
column2: After his father had been put to death by Viṣṇu in the form of the manlion, Prahlāda became the sovereign of the Daityas and possessing the splendours of royalty consequent upon his piety, exercised extensive sway, and was blessed with a numerous progeny.

column1: kṣīṇādhikāraḥ sa yadā puṇyapāpavivirjitaḥ / tadā sa bhagavaddhyānātparaṃ nīrvāṇamāppavān //
column2: At the expiration of an authority which was the reward of his meritorious acts, he was freed from the consequences of moral merit or demerit, and obtained, through meditation on the deity, final exemption from existence.

column1: evaṃ prabhāvo daityo 'sau maitreyāsīn mahāmatiḥ / prahlādo bhagavadbhakto yaṃ tvaṃ mām anupṛcchasi //
column2: Such, Maitreya, was the Daitya Prahlāda, the wise and faithful worshipper of Viṣṇu, of whom you wished to hear and such was his miraculous power.

column1: yastvetaccārītaṃ tasya prahlādasya mahātmanaḥ / śṛṇoti tasya pāpāni sadyo gacchanti saṃkṣayam // ahorātrakṛtaṃ pāpaṃ prahlādacaritaṃ naraḥ / śṛṇvan paṭhaṃś ca maitreya vyapohati na saṃśayaḥ //
column2: Whoever listens to the history of Prahlāda is immediately cleansed from his sins the iniquities that he commits, by night or by day, shall be expiated by once hearing, or once reading, the history of Prahlāda.

column1: paurmamāsyāmamāvāsyāmaṣṭamyāmatha vā paṭhan / dvādaśyāṃ tadāprantoti gopradānaphalaṃ dvija //
column2: The perusal of this history on the day of full moon, of new moon, or on the eighth or twelfth day of the lunation, shall yield fruit equal to the donation of a cow.

column1: prahlādaṃ sakalāpatsu yathā rakṣitavānhariḥ / tathā rakṣati yastasya śṛṇoti caritaṃ sadā // iti śrīviṣṇupurāṇe prathameṃśodhyāyaḥ
column2: As Viṣṇu protected Prahlāda in all the calamities to which he was exposed, so shall the deity protect him who listens constantly to the tale.

column1: prahlādaputra āyuṣmāñchibirbāṣkala eva ca / virocanastu prāhladirbalirjajñe virocanāt // baleḥ putraśataṃ tvasīdbāṇajyeṣṭhaṃ mahāmune / hiraṇyākṣasutāścāsansarva eva mahā balā // jharjharaḥ śakuniścaiva bhūtasantāpanas tathā / mahānābho mahābāhuḥ kālanābhastathāparaḥ //
column2: THE sons of Sanhrāda, the son of Hiraṇyakaśipu, were Āyushmān, Śivi, and Vāṣkala. Prahlāda had a son named Virocana whose son was Bali, who had a hundred sons, of whom Bāṇa was the eldest. Hiraṇyākṣa also had many sons, all of whom were Daityas of great prowess Jharjhara, Śakuni, Bhūtasantāpana, Mahānābha, the mightyarmed and the valiant Tāraka.

column1: abhavandanupūtrāś ca dvimūrdha śaṃbaras tathā / ayomukhaḥ śaṅkuśirāḥ kapilaḥ śaṅkaras tathā // ekacakro mahābāhustārakaś ca mahābalaḥ / svarbhānurvṛṣaparvā ca puloma ca mahābalaḥ //
column2: The children of Kaśyapa by Danu were Dvimūrddhā, Śaṅkara, Ayomukha, Śaṅkuśiras, Kapila, Samvara, Ekacakra, and another mighty Tāraka, Swarbhānu, Vṛṣaparvan, Puloman, and the powerful Viprachitti these were the renowned Dānavas, or sons of Danu.

column1: svarbhānostu prabhā kanyā śarmiṣṭhā vārṣaparvaṇī / upadānī hayaśiraḥ prakhyātā varakanyakāḥ //
column2: Swarbhānu had a daughter named Prabhā and Śarmiṣṭhā was the daughter of Vṛṣaparvan, as were Upadānavī and Hayaśirā.

column1: vaiśvānarasute cobhe pulomā kālakā tathā / ubhe sute mahābhāge mārīcestu parigrahaḥ // tābhyā putrasahasrāṇi ṣaṣṭirdānavasattamāḥ / paulomāḥ kālake yāś ca mārīcatanayāḥ smṛtāḥ //
column2: Vaisvānara had two daughters, Pulomā and Kālikā, who were both married to Kaśyapa, and bore him sixty thousand distinguished Dānavas, called Paulomas and Kālakañjas, who were powerful, ferocious, and cruel.

column1: tryaṃśaḥ śalyaś ca balavān nabhaścaiva mahābalaḥ / vātāpī namuciścaiva ilvalaḥ khasṛmas tathā // āndhako narakaścaiva kālanābhastathaiva ca / svarbhānuś ca mahāvīryo vaktrayodhī mahāsuraḥ //
column2: The sons of Viprachitti by Sinhikā the sister of Hiraṇyakaśipu were Vyaṃśa, Śalya the strong, Nabha the powerful, Vātāpi, Namuchi, Ilwala, Khasrima, Añjaka, Naraka, and Kālanābha, the valiant Swarbhānu, and the mighty Vaktrayodhī.

column1: ete vai dānavāḥ śreṣṭhā danuvaṃśavivardhanāḥ / eteṣāṃ putrapautraś ca śataśo 'tha sahasraśaḥ //
column2: These were the most eminent Dānavas, through whom the race of Danu was multiplied by hundreds and thousands through succeeding generations.

column1: prahlādasya tu daityasya nivāta kavacāḥ kule / samutpannāḥ sumahatā tapasā bhāvitātmanaḥ //
column2: In the family of the Daitya Prahlāda, the Nivāta Kavacas were born, whose spirits were purified by rigid austerity.

column1: ṣaṭ sutāḥ sumahāsattvāstāmrāyāḥ parikīrtitāḥ / śukī śyenī ca bhāsī ca sugrīvī śucigṛddhrakā // śukī śukānajanayadulūkapratyulūkikān / śyenī śyenāṃs tathā bhāsī bhāsāngṛrdhyāṃś ca gṛddhryapi //
column2: Tāmrā the wife of Kaśyapa had six illustrious daughters, named Śukī, Śyenī, Bhāsī, Sugrīvī, Śuci, and Gridhrikā. Śukī gave birth to parrots, owls, and crows Śyenī to hawks Bhāsī to kites Gridhrikā to vultures Śuci to waterfowl Sugrīvī to horses, camels, and asses.

column1: vinatāyāstu dvau putrau viratau garuḍāruṇau / suparṇaḥ patatāṃ śreṣṭho dāruṇaḥ pannagāśanaḥ //
column2: Vinatā bore to Kaśyapa two celebrated sons, Garuḍa and Aruṇa the former, also called Suparṇa, was the king of the feathered tribes, and the remorseless enemy of the serpent race.

column1: surasāyāṃ sahasraṃ tu sarpāṇāmamitaujasām / anekaśirasāṃ brahman khecarāmāṃ mahātmanām //
column2: The children of Surasā were a thousand mighty manyheaded serpents, traversing the sky.

column1: teṣāṃ pradhānabhūtāstu śeṣavāsukitakṣakāḥ / śaṅkhaśveto mahāpadmaḥ kambalāśvatarau tathā // elāputras tathā nāgaḥ karkoṭakadhanañjayau / ete cānye ca bahavo dandaśukā viṣolbaṇā //
column2: The progeny of Kadru were a thousand powerful manyheaded serpents, of immeasurable might, subject to Garuḍa the chief amongst whom were Śeṣa, Vāsuki, Takṣaka, Śaṅkha, Śveta, Mahāpadma, Kambala, Āswatara, Elāpatra, Nāga, Karkkota, Dhanañjaya, and many other fierce and venomous serpents.

column1: gaṇaṃ krodhavaśaṃ viddhi tasyāḥ sarve ca daṃṣṭriṇaḥ / sthalajāḥ pakṣiṇobjāś ca dāruṇāḥ piśitāśanāḥ //
column2: The family of Krodhavasā were all sharptoothed monsters, whether on the earth, amongst the birds, or in the waters, that were devourers of flesh.

column1: ete kaśyapadāyādāḥ kīrtitāḥ sthāṇujaṅgamāḥ / teṣāṃ putrāś ca pautrāś ca śataśo 'tha sahasraśaḥ //
column2: These were the children of Kaśyapa, whether movable or stationary, whose descendants multiplied infinitely through successive generations.

column1: eṣa manvantare sargo brahmansvārociṣesmṛtaḥ //
column2: This creation, oh Brahman, took place in the second or Svārociṣa Manvantara.

column1: vaivasvate ca mahati vāruṇe vitate kṛtau / juhvānasya brahmaṇo vai prajāsarga ihocyate // pūrvaṃ yatra tu saptarṣinutpannānsaptamānasān / putratve kalpayāmāsa svayameva pitāmahaḥ / gandharvabhogidevānāṃ dānavānāṃ ca sattama //
column2: In the present or Vaivaswata Manvantara, Brahmā being engaged at the great sacrifice instituted by Varuṇa, the creation of progeny, as it is called, occurred for he begot, as his sons, the seven Ṛṣis, who were formerly mindengendered and was himself the grandsire of the Gandharvas, serpents, Dānavas, and gods.

column1: ditirvinaṣṭaputrā vai toṣayāmāsa kāśyapam / tayā cārādhitaḥ samyakkāśyapastapatāṃ paraḥ // vareṇa cchandayāmāsa sā ca vavre tato varam / putramindravadhārthāya samarthama mitaujasam // sa ca tasmai varaṃ prādādbhāryāyai munisattamaḥ / dattvā ca varamatyugraṃ kaśyapastāmuvāca ha // śakraṃ putro nihantā te yadi garbhaṃ śaracchatam / samāhitātiprayatā śaucinī dhārayiṣyasi //
column2: Diti, having lost her children, propitiated Kaśyapa and the best of ascetics, being pleased with her, promised her a boon on which she prayed for a son of irresistible prowess and valour, who should destroy Indra. The excellent Muni granted his wife the great gift she had solicited, but with one condition “You shall bear a son,” he said, “who shall slay Indra, if with thoughts wholly pious, and person entirely pure, you carefully carry the babe in your womb for a hundred years.” Having thus said, Kaśyapa departed and the dame conceived, and during gestation assiduously observed the rules of mental and personal purity.

column1: ityevasuktvā tāṃ devīṃ saṃgataḥ kaśyapo muniḥ / dadhāra sā ca taṃ garbhaṃ samyakchocasamanvitā // garbhamātmavadhārthāya jñātvā taṃ maghavānapi / śuśrūṣustāmathāgacchadvinayādamarādhipaḥ //
column2: When the king of the immortals, learnt that Diti bore a son destined for his destruction, he came to her, and attended upon her with the utmost humility, watching for an opportunity to disappoint her intention.

column1: tasyā ścaivāntaraprepsuratiṣṭhatpākaśāsanaḥ / ūne varṣaśate cāsyā dadarśāntaramātmanā // akṛtvā pādayoḥ śaucaṃ ditiḥ śayanamāviśat / nidrāṃ cāhārayāmāsa tasyāḥ kukṣiṃ praviśya saḥ //
column2: At last, in the last year of the century, the opportunity occurred. Diti retired one night to rest without performing the prescribed ablution of her feet, and fell asleep on which the thunderer divided with his thunderbolt the embryo in her womb into seven portions.

column1: vajrapāṇirmahāgarbhaṃ cicchedātha sa saptadhā / sampīḍyamāno pajreṇa sa rurodādidāruṇam // mā rodīriti taṃ śakraḥ punaḥpunarabhāṣata / so 'bhavatsaptadhā garbhastamidraḥ kupitaḥ punaḥ // ekaikaṃ saptadhā cakre vajreṇārividāriṇā / maruto nāma devāste babhūvurativeginaḥ // yaduktaṃ vai bhagavatā tenaiva maruto 'bhavan / devā ekonapachcāśatsahāyā vajrapāṇinaḥ //
column2: The child, thus mutilated, cried bitterly and Indra repeatedly attempted to console and silence it, but in vain on which the god, being incensed, again divided each of the seven portions into seven, and thus formed the swiftmoving deities called Mārutas winds. They derived this appellation from the words with which Indra had addressed them Mā rodīh, ‘Weep not’ and they became fortynine subordinate divinities, the associates of the wielder of the thunderbolt.

column1: iti śriviṣṇupurāme prathamaiṃśa ekaviṃśodhyāyaḥ
column2: Viṣṇu every thing. Merit of hearing the first book of the Viṣṇu Purāṇa.

column1: yadābhiṣiktaḥ sa pṛthuḥ pūrvaṃ rājye maharṣibhiḥ / tataḥ krameṇa rājyāni dadau lokapitāmahaḥ //
column2: WHEN Prithu was installed in the government of the earth, the great father of the spheres established sovereignties in other parts of the creation.

column1: nakṣatragrahaviprāṇāṃ vīrudhāṃ cāpyaśeṣataḥ / somaṃ rājye dadhadbrahma yajñānāṃ tapasāmapi //
column2: Soma was appointed monarch of the stars and planets, of Brahmans and of plants, of sacrifices and of penance.

column1: rājñāṃ vaiśravaṇaṃ rājye jalānāṃ varuṇaṃ tathā / ādityānāṃ patiṃ viṣṇuṃ vasūnāmatha pāvakam //
column2: Vaisravaṇa was made king over kings and Varuṇa, over the waters. Viṣṇu was the chief of the Ādityas Pāvaka, of the Vasus Dakṣa, of the patriarchs Vāsava, of the winds.

column1: prajāpatīnāṃ dakṣaṃ tu vāsavaṃ marutāmapi / daityānāṃ dānavānāṃ ca prahlādamadhipaṃ dadau //
column2: To Prahlāda was assigned dominion over the Daityas and Dānavas and Yama, the king of justice, was appointed the monarch of the Manes Pitris.

column1: patatriṇāṃ tu guruḍaṃ devānāmapi vāsavam / uccaiḥśravasamaśvānāṃ vṛṣabhaṃ tu gavāmapi //
column2: Airāvata was made the king of elephants Garuḍa, of birds Indra, of the gods. Uccaiśravas was the chief of horses Vṛṣabha, of kine.

column1: himālayaṃ sthāvaraṇāṃ munīnāṃ kapilaṃ munim / nakhināṃ deṣṭriṇāṃ caiva mṛgāṇāṃ vyāghramīśvaram //
column2: Śeṣa became the snakeking the lion, the monarch of the beasts and the sovereign of the trees was the holy figtree.

column1: evaṃ vibhajya rājyāni diśāṃ pālānanantaram / prajāpatipatirbrahmā sthāpayāmāsa sarvataḥ // pūrvasyāṃ diśi rājānaṃ vairājasya prajāpateḥ / diśāpālaṃ sudhanvānaṃ sutaṃ vai so 'bhyaṣecayat // dakṣiṇasyāṃ diśi tathā kardamasya prajāpateḥ / putraṃ śaṅkhapadaṃ nāma rājānaṃ so 'bhyaṣecayat //
column2: Having thus fixed the limits of each authority, the great progenitor Brahmā stationed rulers for the protection of the different quarters of the world he made Sudhanwan, the son of the patriarch Viraja, the regent of the east Saṅkhapāda, the son of the patriarch Kardama, of the south the immortal Ketumat, the son of Rajas, regent of the west and Hiraṇyaroman, the son of the patriarch Parjanya, regent of the north.

column1: tair iyaṃ pṛthivī sarvā saptadvīpā sapattanā / yathāpradeśamadyāpi dharmataḥ paripālyate //
column2: By these the whole earth, with its seven continents and its cities, is to the present day vigilantly protected, according to their several limits.

column1: ete sarve pravṛttasya sthitau viṣṇormahātmanaḥ / vibhūtibhūtā rājāno ye cānye munisattama // ye bhaviṣyanti ye bhūtāḥ sarve bhūteśvarā dvija / te sarve sarvabhūtasya viṣṇoraṃśā dvijottama //
column2: All these monarchs, and whatever others may be invested with authority by the mighty Viṣṇu, as instruments for the preservation of the world all the kings who have been, and all who shall be are all, most worthy Brahman, but portions of the universal Viṣṇu.

column1: ye tu devādhipatayo ye ca daityādhipās tathā / dānavānāṃ ca ye nāthā ye nāthāḥ piśitāśinām // paśunāṃ ye ca patayaḥ patayo ye ca pakṣiṇām / manuṣyāṇāṃ ca sarpāṇāṃ nāgānāmadhipāś ca ye // vṛkṣāṇāṃ parvatānāṃ ca grahāṇāṃ cāpi ye 'dhipāḥ / atītā vartamānāś ca ye bhaviṣyanti cāpare / te sarve sarvabhūtasya viṣṇoraṃśasamudbhāvāḥ //
column2: The rulers of the gods, the rulers of the Daityas, the rulers of the Dānavas, and the rulers of all malignant spirits the chief amongst beasts, amongst birds, amongst men, amongst serpents the best of trees, of mountains, of planets either those that now are, or that shall hereafter be, the most exalted of their kind are but portions of the universal Viṣṇu.

column1: na hi pālanasāmarthyamṛte sarveśvaraṃ harim / sthitaṃ sthitau mahāprājña bhavatyanyasya kasyacit //
column2: The power of protecting created things, the preservation of the world, resides with no other than Hari, the lord of all.

column1: sṛjatyeṣa jagatsṛṣṭau sthitau pāti sanātanaḥ / hanti caivāntakatvena rajaḥsattvādisaṃśrayaḥ //
column2: He is the creator, who creates the world he, the eternal, preserves it in its existence and he, the destroyer, destroys it invested severally with the attributes of foulness, goodness, and gloom.

column1: caturvibhāgaḥ saṃsṛṣṭau caturdhā saṃsthitaḥ sthitau / pralayaṃ ca karotyante caturbhedo janārdanaḥ //
column2: By a fourfold manifestation does Janārddana operate in creation, preservation, and destruction.

column1: ekenāṃśena brahmasau bhavatyavyaktamūrtimān / marīcimiśrāḥ patayaḥ prajānāñcānyabhāgaśaḥ // kālastṛtīyastasyāṃśaḥ sarvabhūtāni cāparaḥ / itthaṃ caturdhā saṃsṛṣṭau vartatesau rajoguṇaḥ //
column2: In one portion, as Brahmā, the invisible assumes a visible form in another portion he, as Marīci and the rest, is the progenitor of all creatures his third portion is time his fourth is all beings and thus he becomes quadruple in creation, invested with the quality of passion.

column1: ekāṃśenāsthito viṣṇuḥ karoti pratipālanam / manvādirūpaścānyena kālarūpo 'paroṇa ca // sarvabhūteṣu cānyena saṃśthitaḥ kurute sthitim / sattvaṃ guṇaṃ samāśritya jagataḥ puruṣottamaḥ //
column2: In the preservation of the world he is, in one portion, Viṣṇu in another portion he is Manu and the other patriarchs he is time in a third and all beings in a fourth portion and thus, endowed with the property of goodness, Puruṣottama preserves the world.

column1: āśritya tamaso vṛttimantakāle tathā punaḥ / rudrasvarūpo bhagavānekāṃśena bhavatyajaḥ // agnyantakādirūpeṇa bhāgenānyena vartate / kālasvarūpo bhāgo yaḥsarvabhūtāni cāparaḥ //
column2: When he assumes the property of darkness, at the end of all things, the unborn deity becomes in one portion Rudra in another, the destroying fire in a third, time and in a fourth, all beings and thus, in a quadruple form, he is the destroyer of the world.

column1: vināśaṃ kurvatastasya caturdhaivaṃ mahātmanaḥ / vibhāgakalpanā brahman kathyate sārvakālikī //
column2: This, Brahman, is the fourfold condition of the deity at all seasons.

column1: brahma dakṣādayaḥ kālastathai vākhilajantavaḥ / vibhūtayo hareretā jagataḥ sṛṣṭihetavaḥ //
column2: Brahmā, Dakṣa, time, and all creatures are the four energies of Hari, which are the causes of creation.

column1: viṣṇurmanvādayaḥ kālaḥ sarvabhūtāni ca dvija / sthiternimittabhūtasya viṣṇoretā vibhūtayaḥ //
column2: Viṣṇu, Manu and the rest, time, and all creatures are the four energies of Viṣṇu, which are the causes of duration.

column1: rudraḥ kālāntakādyāś ca samastāścaiva jantavaḥ / caturdhā pralāyāyaitā janārdanavibhūtayaḥ //
column2: Rudra, the destroying fire, time, and all creatures are the four energies of Janārddana that are exerted for universal dissolution.

column1: jagadādau tathā madhye sṛṣṭirāpralayā dvija / dhātrā marīcimiśraiś ca kriyate jantubhis tathā // brahma sṛjatyādikāle marīcipramukhāstataḥ / utpādayantyapatyāni jantavaś ca pratikṣaṇam // kālena na vinā brahma sṛṣṭiniṣpādako dvija / na prajāpatayaḥ sarve na caivākhilajantavaḥ //
column2: In the beginning and the duration of the world, until the period of its end, creation is the work of Brahmā, the patriarchs, and living animals. Brahmā creates in the beginning then the patriarchs beget progeny and then animals incessantly multiply their kinds but Brahmā is not the active agent in creation, independent of time neither are the patriarchs, nor living animals.

column1: evameva vibhāgoyaṃ stitāvapyupadiśyati / caturdā tasya devasya maitreya pralaye tathā //
column2: So, in the periods of creation and of dissolution, the four portions of the god of gods are equally essential.

column1: yatkiñcitsṛjyate yena sattvajātena vai dvija / tasya sṛjyasya sambhūto tatsarvaṃ vai harestanuḥ // hanti yāvacca yatkiñcitsattvaṃ sthāvarajaṅgamam / janārdanasya tadraudraṃ maitreyāntakaraṃ vatuḥ //
column2: Whatever, oh Brahman, is engendered by any living being, the body of Hari is cooperative in the birth of that being so whatever destroys any existing thing, movable or stationary, at any time, is the destroying form of Janārddana as Rudra.

column1: evameṣa jagatstraṣṭā jagatpātā tathā jagat / jagadbhakṣayitā devaḥ samastasya janārdanaḥ // sṛṣṭhisthityantakāleṣu tridhaivaṃ saṃpravartate / guṇapravṛtyā paramaṃ padaṃ tasyāguṇaṃ mahat // tacca jñānamayaṃ vyāpi svāsaṃvedyamanaupamam / catuṣprakāraṃ tadapi svarūpaṃ paramātmanaḥ //
column2: Thus Janārddana is the creator, the preserver, and the destroyer of the whole world—being threefold—in the several seasons of creation, preservation, and destruction, according to his assumption of the three qualities but his highest glory is detached from all qualities for the fourfold essence of the supreme spirit is composed of true wisdom, pervades all things, is only to be appreciated by itself, and admits of no similitude.

column1: catuḥprakāratāṃ tasya brahmabhūtasya he mune / mamācakṣva yathānyāyaṃ yaduktaṃ paramaṃ padam //
column2: But, Muni, describe to me fully the four varieties of the condition of Brahma, and what is the supreme condition.

column1: maitreya kāraṇaṃ proktaṃ sādhanaṃ sarvavastuṣu / sādhyaṃ ca vastvabhimataṃ yatsādhayitumātmanaḥ //
column2: That, Maitreya, which is the cause of a thing is called the means of effecting it and that which it is the desire of the soul to accomplish is the thing to be effected.

column1: yogino muktikāmasya prāṇāyāmādisādhanam / sādhyaṃ ca paramaṃ brahma punarnavartateyataḥ //
column2: The operations of the Yogi who is desirous of liberation, as suppression of breath and the like, are his means the end is the supreme Brahma, whence he returns to the world no more.

column1: sādhanālambanaṃ jñānaṃ muktaye yogināṃ hi yat / sa bhedaḥ prathamastasya brahmabhūtasya vai mune // yuñjataḥ kleśamuktyarthaṃ sādhyaṃ yadbrahma yoginaḥ / tadālambanavijñānaṃ dvitīyo 'ṃśo mahāmune // ubhayostvavibhāgena sādhyasādhanayorhi yat / vijñānamadvaitamayaṃ tadbhāgonyo mayoditaḥ //
column2: Essentially connected with, and dependant upon, the means employed for emancipation by the Yogi, is discriminative knowledge and this is the first variety of the condition of Brahma. The second sort is the knowledge that is to be acquired by the Yogi whose end is escape from suffering, or eternal felicity. The third kind is the ascertainment of the identity of the end and the means, the rejection of the notion of duality.

column1: jñānatrayasya vai tasya viśeṣo yo mahāmune / tannirākaraṇadvārā darśitātmasvarūpavat //
column2: The last kind is the removal of whatever differences may have been conceived by the three first varieties of knowledge, and the consequent contemplation of the true essence of soul.

column1: nirvyāpāramanākhyeyaṃ vyāptimātramanūpamam / ātmasambodhaviṣayaṃ sattāmātramalakṣaṇam // praśāntamabhayaṃ śuddhaṃ durvibhāvyamasaṃśrayam / viṣṇorjñānamayasyoktaṃ tajjñānaṃ brahmasaṃjñitam //
column2: The supreme condition of Viṣṇu, who is one with wisdom, is the knowledge of truth which requires no exercise which is not to be taught which is internally diffused which is unequalled the object of which is selfillumination which is simply existent, and is not to be defined which is tranquil, fearless, pure which is not the theme of reasoning which stands in need of no support.

column1: tatra jñānanirodhena yogino yānti ye layam / saṃsārakarṣaṇoptau te yānti nirbījatāṃ dvijā //
column2: Those Yogis who, by the annihilation of ignorance, are resolved into this fourfold Brahma, lose the seminal property, and can no longer germinate in the ploughed field of worldly existence.

column1: evaṃprakāramamalaṃ nityaṃ vyāpakamakṣayam / samastaheyarahitaṃ viṣṇvākhyaṃ paramaṃ padam // tadbrahma paramaṃ yogī yato nāvartate punaḥ / śrayatyapuṇyoparame kṣīṇakleśe 'tinirmale //
column2: This is the supreme condition, that is called Viṣṇu, perfect, perpetual, universal, undecaying, entire, and uniform and the Yogi who attains this supreme spirit Brahma returns not to life again for there he is freed from the distinction of virtue and vice, from suffering, and from soil.

column1: dve rūpe brahmaṇastasya mūrta cāmūrtameva ca / kṣarākṣarāsvarūpe te sarvabhūteṣvavasthite //
column2: There are two states of this Brahma one with, and one without shape one perishable, and one imperishable which are inherent in all beings.

column1: akṣaraṃ tatparaṃ brahma kṣaraṃ sarvamidaṃ jagat / ekadeśasthitasyāgnerjyotstrā vistāriṇi yathā / parasya brahmaṇaḥ śaktistathodamakhilaṃ jagat // tatrāpyāsannadūratvād bahutvasvalpatāmayaḥ / jyotsnābhedosti tacchaktestadvanmaitreya vidyate //
column2: The imperishable is the supreme being the perishable is all the world. The blaze of fire burning on one spot diffuses light and heat around so the world is nothing more than the manifested energy of the supreme Brahma and inasmuch, Maitreya, as the light and heat are stronger or feebler as we are near to the fire, or far off from it, so the energy of the supreme is more or less intense in the beings that are less or more remote from him.

column1: ba3hmaviṣṇuśivā brahmanpradhānā brahmaśaktayaḥ / tataś ca devā maitreya nyūnā dakṣādayastataḥ // tato manuṣyāḥ paśavau mṛgapakṣisarīsṛpāḥ / nyūnānyūnatarāścaiva vṛkṣagulmādayas tathā //
column2: Brahma, Viṣṇu, and Śiva are the most powerful energies of god next to them are the inferior deities, then the attendant spirits, then men, then animals, birds, insects, vegetables each becoming more and more feeble as they are farther from their primitive source.

column1: tadetadakṣaraṃ nityaṃ jaganmunivarākhitam / āvirbhāvatirobhāvajanmanāśavikalpavat //
column2: In this way, illustrious Brahman, this whole world, although in essence imperishable and eternal, appears and disappears, as if it was subject to birth and death.

column1: sarvaśakti mayo viṣṇuḥ svarūpaṃ brahmaṇaḥ param / mūrtaṃ yadyogibhiḥ purvaṃ yogārambheṣu cintyate // sālambano mahāyogaḥ sabījo yatrasaṃsthitaḥ / manasyavyāhate samyagyuñjatāṃ jāyate mune //
column2: The supreme condition of Brahma, which is meditated by the Yogis in the commencement of their abstraction, as invested with form, is Viṣṇu, composed of all the divine energies, and the essence of Brahma, with whom the mystic union that is sought, and which is accompanied by suitable elements, is effected by the devotee whose whole mind is addressed to that object.

column1: sa paraḥ paraśaktīnāṃ brahmaṇaḥ samanantaram / mūrtaṃ brahma mahābhāga sarvabrahmamayo hariḥ // yatra sarvamidaṃ protamotaṃ caivākhitaṃ jagat / tato jagajjagatyasminsa jagaccakhilaṃ mune // kṣarākṣaramayo viṣṇurbibhartyakhilamīśvaraḥ / puruṣāvyākṛtamayaṃ bhūṣaṇāstrasvarūpavat //
column2: This Hari, who is the most immediate of all the energies of Brahma, is his embodied shape, composed entirely of his essence and in him therefore is the whole world interwoven and from him, and in him, is the universe and he, the supreme lord of all, comprising all that is perishable and imperishable, bears upon him all material and spiritual existence, identified in nature with his ornaments and weapons.

column1: bhūṣaṇāstrasvarūpasthaṃ yaccaitadakhilaṃ jagat / bibharti bhagavanviṣṇu stanmamākhyātumarhasi //
column2: Tell me in what manner Viṣṇu bears the whole world, abiding in his nature, characterised by ornaments and weapons.

column1: namaskṛtvāprameyāya viṣṇave prabhaviṣṇave / kathayāmi yathākhyātaṃ vasiṣṭhena mamā bhavat //
column2: Having offered salutation to the mighty and indescribable Viṣṇu, I repeat to you what was formerly related to me by Vaśiṣṭha.

column1: ātmānamasya jagato nirlepamaguṇāmalam / bibharti kaustubhamaṇisvarūpaṃ bhagavānhariḥ //
column2: The glorious Hari wears the pure soul of the world, undefiled, and void of qualities, as the Kaustubha gem.

column1: śrīvatsasaṃsthānadhara manante na samāśritam / pradhānaṃ buddhirapyāste gadarūpeṇa mādhave //
column2: The chief principle of things Pradhāna is seated on the eternal, as the Srivatsa mark. Intellect abides in Mādhava, in the form of his mace.

column1: bhūtādimindriyādiṃ ca dvidhāhaṅkāramīśvaraḥ / bibharti śaṃkharūpeṇa śārṅgarūpeṇa ca sthitam //
column2: The lord Īśvara supports egotism Ahaṅkāra in its twofold division, into elements and organs of sense, in the emblems of his conchshell and his bow.

column1: calatsvarūpamatyantaṃ javenāntāritānilam / cakrasvarūpaṃ ca mano dhatte viṣṇukare sthitam //
column2: In his hand Viṣṇu holds, in the form of his discus, the mind, whose thoughts like the weapon fly swifter than the winds.

column1: pañcarūpā tu yā mālā vaijayantī gadābhṛtaḥ / sā bhūtahetusaṃghātā bhūtamālā ca vai dvija //
column2: The necklace of the deity Vaijayantī, composed of five precious gems, is the aggregate of the five elemental rudiments.

column1: yānīndriyāṇyaśeṣāṇi buddhikarmātmakāni vai / śararūpāṇyaśeṣāṇi tāni dhatte janārdanaḥ //
column2: Janārddana bears, in his numerous shafts, the faculties both of action and of perception.

column1: bibharti yaccāsiratnamacyutotyantanirmalam / vidyāmaya tu tajjñānamavidyākośasaṃsthitam //
column2: The bright sword of Achyuta is holy wisdom, concealed at some seasons in the scabbard of ignorance.

column1: itthaṃ pumānpradhānaṃ ca buddhyahaṅkārameva ca / bhūtāni ca hṛṣīkeśe manaḥ sarvendriyāṇi ca / vidyāvidye ca maitreya sarvametatsamāśritam //
column2: In this manner soul, nature, intellect, egotism, the elements, the senses, mind, ignorance, and wisdom, are all assembled in the person of Hṛṣikeśa.

column1: astrabhūṣaṇasaṃsthānasvarūpaṃ rūpavarjitaḥ / bibhārti māyārūposau śreyase prāṇināṃ hariḥ //
column2: Hari, in a delusive form, embodies the shapeless elements of the world, as his weapons and his ornaments, for the salvation of mankind.

column1: savikāraṃ pradhānaṃ ca pumāṃścaivākhilaṃ jagat / bibharti puṇḍahīkākṣastadevaṃ parameśvaraḥ //
column2: Puṇḍarikākṣa, the lord of all, assumes nature, with all its products, soul and all the world.

column1: yā vidyā yā tathāvidyā yatsadyaccāsadavyayam / tatsarvaṃ sarvabhūteśe maitreya madhusūdane //
column2: All that is wisdom, all that is ignorance, all that is, all that is not, all that is everlasting, is centred in the destroyer of Madhu, the lord of all creatures.

column1: kalākāṣṭhānimeṣādidinartvayanahāyanaiḥ / kālasvarūpo bhagavānapāpo hariravyayaḥ // bhūrlokotha bhuvarlokaḥ svarloko munisattama / maharjanastapaḥ satyaṃ sapta lokā ime vibhuḥ // lokātmamūrtiḥ sarveṣāṃ pūrveṣāmapi pūrvajaḥ / ādhāraḥ sarvavidyānāṃ svayameva hariḥ sthitaḥ // devamānuṣapaśvādiśvarūpair bahubhiḥ sthitaḥ / tataḥ sarveśvaro 'nanto bhūtamūrtiramūrtimān // ṛco yajūṃṣi sāmāni tathaivātharvāṇāni vai / itihāsopavedāś ca vedānteṣu tathoktayaḥ //
column2: The supreme, eternal Hari is time, with its divisions of seconds, minutes, days, months, seasons, and years he is the seven worlds, the earth, the sky, heaven, the world of patriarchs, of sages, of saints, of truth whose form is all worlds firstborn before all the firstborn the supporter of all beings, himself selfsustained who exists in manifold forms, as gods, men, and animals and is thence the sovereign lord of all, eternal whose shape is all visible things who is without shape or form who is celebrated in the Vedanta as the Rich, Yajush, Sāma, and Atharva Vedas, inspired history, and sacred science.

column1: vedāṅgāni samastāni manvādigaditāni ca / śāstrāṇyaśeṣāṇyākhyānāny anuvākāś ca ye kvacit // kāvyālāpāś ca ye kecidrītakānyakhilāni ca / śabdamūrtidharasyaitad vapurviṣṇor mahātmanaḥ //
column2: The Vedas, and their divisions the institutes of Manu and other lawgivers traditional scriptures, and religious manuals poems, and all that is said or sung are the body of the mighty Viṣṇu, assuming the form of sound.

column1: yāni mūrtāny amūrtāni yānyatrānyatra vā kvacit / santi vai vastujātāni tāni sarvāṇi tadvapuḥ //
column2: All kinds of substances, with or without shape, here or elsewhere, are the body of Viṣṇu.

column1: ahaṃ hariḥ sarvamidaṃ janārdano nānyattataḥ kāraṇakāryajātam / īdṛṅmano yasya na tasyaṭa bhūyo bhavodbhāvā dvandvagadā bhavanti //
column2: I am Hari. All that I behold is Janārddana cause and effect are from none other than him. The man who knows these truths shall never again experience the afflictions of worldly existence.

column1: ityaiṣa teṃśaḥ prathamaḥ purāṇasyāsya vai dvija / yathāvatkathito yasmindhṛte pāpaiḥ pramucyate //
column2: Thus, Brahman, has the first portion of this Purāṇa been duly revealed to you listening to which, expiates all offences.

column1: kārttikyāṃ puṣkarasnāne dvādaśābdena yatphalam / tadasya śravaṇātsava maitreyāpnoti mānavaḥ //
column2: The man who hears this Purāṇa obtains the fruit of bathing in the Puṣkara lake for twelve years, in the month of Kārtik.

column1: devarṣipitṛgandharvayakṣādināṃ ca sambhavam / bhavanti śṛṇvataḥ puṃso devādya varadā mune //
column2: The gods bestow upon him who hears this work the dignity of a divine sage, of a patriarch, or of a spirit of heaven.

column1: iti śriviṣṇumahāpurāṇe prathame 'ṃśe dvāviṃśo 'dhyāyaḥ iti śrīparāśaramuniviracite śriviṣṇuparatvanirṇāyake śrīmati viṣṇumahāpurāṇe prathamāṃśaḥ samāptaḥ / atha śrīviṣṇumahāpurāṇe viṣṇucittyātmaprakāśākhyaśrīdharīya vyākhyādvayopete dvitīyoṃśaḥ prārabhyate śrīmate rāmānujāya namaḥ
column2: Descendants of Priyavrata, the eldest son of Svāyambhuva Manu his ten sons three adopt a religious life the others become kings of the seven Dvīpas, or isles, of the earth. Agnīdhra, king of Jambudvīpa, divides it into nine portions, which he distributes amongst his sons. Nābhi, king of the south, succeeded by Riṣabha and he by Bharata India named after him Bhārata his descendants reign during the Svāyambhuva Manvantara.

column1: bhagavansamyagākhyātaṃ mamaitadakhilaṃ tvāyā / jagataḥ sargasambandhi yatpṛṣṭosi guro mayā // yoyamaṃśo jagatsṛṣṭisambandho gaditastvayā / tatrāhaṃ śrotumicchāmi bhūyopi munisattama //
column2: You have related to me, venerable preceptor, most fully, all that I was curious to hear respecting the creation of the world but there is a part of the subject which I am desirous again to have described.

column1: priyavratottānapādau sutau svāyambhuvasya yau / tayoruttānapādasya dhruvaḥ putrastvayoditaḥ // priyavratasya naivoktā bhavatā dvija santatiḥ / tāmahaṃ śrotumicchāmi prasanno vaktumarhasi //
column2: You stated that Priyavrata and Uttānapāda were the sons of Svāyambhuva Manu, and you repeated the story of Dhruva, the son of Uttānapāda you made no mention of the descendants of Priyavrata, and it is an account of his family that I beg you will kindly communicate to me.

column1: śrīparāśara uvāca kardamasyātmajāṃ kanyāmupayeme prayivrataḥ / samrāṭ kukṣi ca tatkanye daśaputrastathāpare // mahāprajñā mahāvīryā vinītā dayitāḥ pituḥ / priyavratasutāḥ khyātāsteṣāṃ nāmāni me śṛṇu //
column2: Priyavrata married Kāmyā, the daughter of the patriarch Kardama, and had by her two daughters, Samrāt and Kukṣi, and ten sons, wise, valiant, modest, and dutiful, named Agnīdhra, Agnibāhu, Vapushmat, Dyutimat, Medha, Medhatithi, Bhavya, Savala, Putra, and the tenth was Jyotishmat, illustrious by nature as by name.

column1: jyotiṣmāndaśamasteṣāṃ satyanāmā suto 'bhavat / priyavratasya putrāste prakhyātā balavīryataḥ //
column2: These were the sons of Priyavrata, famous for strength and prowess.

column1: medhāgnibāhuputrāstu trayo yogaparāyaṇāḥ / jātismārā mahābhāgāna rājyāya mano dadhuḥ // nirmalāḥ sarvakālantu samastārtheṣu vai mune / cakruḥ kriyāṃ yathānyāyamaphalākākṣiṇo hi te //
column2: Of these, three, or Medha, Putra, and Agnibāhu, adopted a religious life remembering the occurrences of a prior existence, they did not covet dominion, but diligently practised the rites of devotion in due season, wholly disinterested, and looking for no reward.

column1: priyavrato dadau teṣāṃ saptānāṃ munisattama / saptadvīpāni maitreya vibhajya sumahātmanām //

column2: Nābhi, who had for his portion the country of Himāhwa, had by his queen Meru the magnanimous Riṣabha and he had a hundred sons, the eldest of whom was Bharata.

column1: ṛṣabhādbhārato jajñe jyeṣṭhaḥ putraśatasya saḥ / kṛtvā rājyaṃ svadharmeṇa tathaiṣṭvā vividhānmakhān // abhiṣicya sutaṃ vīraṃ bharataṃ pṛthivīpatiḥ / tapase sa mahābhāgaḥ pulahasyāśramaṃ yayau // vānaprasthavidhānena tatrāpi kṛtaniścayaḥ / tapastepe yathānyāyamiyāja sa mahīpatiḥ // tapasā karṣitotyarthaṃ kṛśo dhamanisantataḥ / nagno vīṭāṃ mukhe kṛtvā vīrādhvānaṃ tato gataḥ //

column1: tataś ca bhārataṃ varṣametallokeṣu gīyate / bharatāya yataḥ pitrā dattaṃ prātiṣṭhatā vanam //

column2: Bharata, having religiously discharged the duties of his station, consigned the kingdom to his son Sumati, a most virtuous prince and, engaging in devout practices, abandoned his life at the holy place, Śālagrāma he was afterwards born again as a Brahman, in a distinguished family of ascetics.

These and others extend from between the intervals in the body, or from the heart, of Meru.

column1: caturdaśasahasrāṇi yojanānāṃ mahāpurī / merorupari maitreya brahmaṇaḥ prathitā divi // tasyāḥsamantataścāṣṭau diśāsu vidiśāsu ca / indrādilokapālānāṃ prakhyātāḥ pravarāḥ puraḥ //

column1: suramyāṇi tathā tāsu kānanāni purāṇi ca / lakṣmīviṣṇvagnisūryādidevānāṃ muni sattama / tāsvāyatanavaryāṇi juṣṭāni varakinnaraiḥ // gandharvayakṣarakṣāṃsi tathā daiteyadānavāḥ / krīḍanti tāsu ramyāsu śailadroṇīṣvaharnisam //
column2: The vallies embosomed amongst them are the favourite resorts of the Siddhas and Cāraṇas and there are situated upon them agreeable forests, and pleasant cities, embellished with the palaces of Viṣṇu, Lakṣmī, Agni, Sūrya, and other deities, and peopled by celestial spirits whilst the Yakṣas, Rākṣasas, Daityas, and Dānavas pursue their pastimes in the vales.

column1: bhadrāśve bhagavānviṣṇurāste hayaśirā dvija / varājaḥ ketumāle tu bhārate kūrmarūpadhṛk // matsyarūpaś ca govindaḥ kuruṣvāste janārdanaḥ / viśvarūpeṇa sarvatra sarvaḥ sarvatrago hariḥ // sarvasyādhārabhūtosau maitreyāstekhilātmakaḥ //
column2: In the country of Bhadrāśva, Viṣṇu resides as Hayasīrā the horseheaded in Ketumāla, as Varāha the boar in Bhārata, as the tortoise Kūrma in Kuru, as the fish Matsya in his universal form, every where for Hari pervades all places he, Maitreya, is the supporter of all things he is all things.

column2: In the eight realms of Kimpuruṣa and the rest or all exclusive of Bhārata there is no sorrow, nor weariness, nor anxiety, nor hunger, nor apprehension their inhabitants are exempt from all infirmity and pain, and live in uninterrupted enjoyment for ten or twelve thousand years.

column2: THE country that lies north of the ocean, and south of the snowy mountains, is called Bhārata, for there dwelt the descendants of Bharata.

column1: bhāratasyāsya varṣasya navabhādānnaśāmaya / idradvīpaḥ kaseruś ca tāmraparṇāṃ gabhastimān // nāgadvīpas tathā sāmyo gandharvastvatha cāruṇaḥ / ayaṃ tu navamastaṣāṃ dvīpaḥ sāgārasaṃvṛtaḥ //
column2: The Varṣa of Bhārata is divided into nine portions, which I will name to you they are Indradvīpa, Kaserumat, Tāmravarṇa, Gabhastimat, Nāgadvīpa, Saumya, Gandharva, and Vāruṇa the last or ninth Dvīpa is surrounded by the ocean, and is a thousand Yojanas from north to south.

column1: yojanānāṃ sahasraṃ tu dvīpoyaṃ dakṣiṇottarāt / pūrve kirātā yasyānte paścime yavanāḥ sthitāḥ // brāhmaṇāḥ kṣatriyā vaiśyā madhye śabdrāś ca bhāgaśaḥ / ijyāyudhavaṇijyādyair vartayanto vyavasthitāḥ //
column2: On the east of Bhārata dwell the Kirātas the barbarians on the west, the Yavanas in the centre reside Brahmans, Kṣetriyas, Vaiśyas, and Śūdras, occupied in their respective duties of sacrifice, arms, trade, and service.

column1: śatadrūcandrabhāgādyā himayatpādanirgatāḥ / vedasmṛtimukhādyāś ca pārīyātrodbhavā mune // narmadā murasādyāś ca nadyo vindhyādrinirgatāḥ / tāpīpayoṣṇīnirvindhyā prasūkhā ṛkṣasaṃbhavāḥ // godāvarī bhīmarathī kṛṣṇaveṇyādikās tathā / sahyapādodbhavā nadyaḥ smṛtāḥ pāpabhayāpahāḥ // kṛtamālā tāmraparṇiprasukhā malayodbhavāḥ / trisāmā carṣikulyādyā mahendraprabhavāḥ smṛtāḥ //
column2: The Śatadru, Candrabhāgā, and other rivers, flow from the foot of Himālaya the Vedasmriti and others from the Parīpātra mountains the Narmadā and Surasā from the Vindhya hills the Tāpī, Payoṣṇī, and Nirvindhyā from the Rikṣa mountains the Godāverī, Bhimarathī, Kṛṣṇavenī, and others, from the Sahya mountains the Kritamālā, Tāmraparṇī, and others, from the Malaya hills the Trisāmā, Ṛṣikulyā, &c. from the Mahendra and the Ṛṣikulyā, Kumārī, and others, from the Śuktimat mountains.

column1: ṛṣikulyākumārādyāḥ śuktimatpādasambhavāḥ / āsāṃ nadya upānadyaḥ santyanyāś ca sahasraśaḥ //
column2: Of such as these, and of minor rivers, there is an infinite number and many nations inhabit the countries on their borders.

column1: tāsvime kurupāñcālā madhyadeśādayo janāḥ / pūrvadeśādikāścaiva kāmarūpanivāsinaḥ // puṇḍrāḥ kaliṅgā magadhā dakṣiṇādyāś ca sarvaśaḥ / tathāparāntāḥ saurāṣṭrāḥ śūrābhīrāstathārbudāḥ // kārūṣā mālabāścaiva pāriyātra nivāsinaḥ / sauvīrāḥ saindhavā hūṇāḥ sālvāḥ kosalavāsināḥ // mādrārāmāstathāmbaṣṭhā pārasīkādayas tathā / āsāṃ pibanti salilaṃ vasanti sahitāḥ sadā / samīpato mahābhāga hṛṣṭapuṣṭajanākulāḥ //
column2: The principal nations of Bhārata are the Kurus and Pāñcālas, in the middle districts the people of Kāmarupa, in the east the Puṇḍras, Kaliṅgas, Magadhas, and southern nations, are in the south in the extreme west are the Saurāṣṭras, Śūras, Bhīras, Arbudas the Kāruṣas and Mālavas, dwelling along the Pāripātra mountains the Sauvīras, the Saindhavas, the Hūnas, the Sālvas, the people of Śākala, the Madras, the Rāmas, the Ambaṣṭhas, and the Pārasīkas, and others. These nations drink of the water of the rivers above enumerated, and inhabit their borders, happy and prosperous.

column1: catvāri bhārate varṣe yugānyatra mahāmune / kṛtaṃ tretā dvāparañca kaliścānyatra na kvacit // tapastapyanti munayo juhvate cātra yajvanaḥ / dānāni cātra dīyante paralokārthamādarāt //
column2: In the Bhāratavarṣa it is that the succession of four Yugas, or ages, the Krita, the Treta, the Dvāpara, and Kali, takes place that pious ascetics engage in rigorous penance that devout men offer sacrifices and that gifts are distributed all for the sake of another world.

column1: puruṣair yajñapuruṣo jambūdvīpe sadejyate / yajñair yajñamayo viṣṇuranyadvīpeṣu cānyathā //
column2: In Jambudvīpa, Viṣṇu, consisting of sacrifice, is worshipped, as the male of sacrificial rites, with sacrificial ceremonies he is adored under other forms elsewhere.

column1: atrāpi bhārataṃ śreṣṭhaṃ janbūdvīpe mahāmune / yato hi karmabhūreṣā hyatonyā bhogabhūmayaḥ //
column2: Bhārata is therefore the best of the divisions of Jambudvīpa, because it is the land of works the others are places of enjoyment alone.

column1: atra janmasahasrāṇāṃ sahasrair api sattama / kadācillabhate janturmānuṣyaṃ puṇyasaṃcayāt //
column2: It is only after many thousand births, and the aggregation of much merit, that living beings are sometimes born in Bhārata as men.

column1: gāyanti devāḥ kila gītakāni dhanyāstu te bhārata bhūmibhāge / svargāpavargāspadamārgabhūte bhavanti bhūyaḥ puruṣāḥ suratvāt //
column2: The gods themselves exclaim, “Happy are those who are born, even from the condition of gods, as men in Bhāratavarṣa, as that is the way to the pleasures of Paradise, or the greater blessing of final liberation.

column1: karmāṇyasaṃkalpitatatphalāni saṃnyasya viṣṇo paramātmbhūte / avāpya tāṃ karmamahīmanante tasmillayaṃ ye tvamalāḥ prayānti //
column2: Happy are they who, consigning all the unheeded rewards of their acts to the supreme and eternal Viṣṇu, obtain existence in that land of works, as their path to him.

column1: jānīma naitatkva vayaṃ vilīne svargaprade karmaṇi dehabandham / prāpsyāma dhanyāḥ khalu te manuṣyā ye bhārate nendriyaviprahīnāḥ //
column2: We know not, when the acts that have obtained us heaven shall have been fully recompensed, where we shall renew corporeal confinement but we know that those men are fortunate who are born with perfect faculties in Bhāratavarṣa.”

column1: navavarṣaṃ tu maitreya jambudvīpamidaṃ mayā / lakṣayojanavistāraṃ saṃkṣepāt kathitaṃ tava //
column2: I have thus briefly described to you, Maitreya, the nine divisions of Jambudvīpa, which is a hundred thousand Yojanas in extent, and which is encircled, as if by a bracelet, by the ocean of salt water, of similar dimensions.

column1: jambūdvīpaṃ samāvṛtya lakṣayojanavistaraḥ / maitreya valayākāraḥ sthitaḥ kṣārodadhirbahiḥ //
column2: Śūdras, Ābhīras, Daradas, Kāśmīras, with Paṭṭis, Khāsīras, Antacāras or borderers, Pahnavas, and dwellers in mountain caves Girigahvaras, Ātreyas, Bhāradvājas, Stanayoshikas, Proṣakas, Kāliṅga, and tribes of Kirātas, Tomaras, Hansamārgas, and Karabhañjikas.

column1: iti śriviṣṇumahāpurāṇe dvitīye 'ṃśe tṛtīyodhyāyaḥ
column2: Account of kings, divisions, mountains, rivers, and inhabitants of the other Dvīpas, viz.

column1: śrīparāśara uvāca
column2: Extent of the whole.

column1: kṣārodena yathā dvīpo jambūsaṃjño 'bhiveṣṭitaḥ / saṃveṣṭya kṣāramudadhiṃ plakṣadvīpas tathā sthitaḥ //
column2: IN the same manner as Jambudvīpa is girt round about by the ocean of salt water, so that ocean is surrounded by the insular continent of Plakṣa the extent of which is twice that of Jambudvīpa.

column1: sapta medhātitheḥ putrāḥ plakṣadvīpeśvarasya vai / jyeṣṭha śāntahayo nāma śiśirastadanantaraḥ // sukhodayastathānandaḥ śivaḥ kṣemaka eva ca / dhruvaś ca saptamasteṣāṃ plakṣadvīpeśvarā hi te //
column2: Medhatithi, who was made sovereign of Plakṣa, had seven sons, Śāntabhaya, Śiśira, Sukhodaya, Ānanda, Śiva, Kṣemaka, and Dhruva and the Dvīpa was divided amongst them, and each division was named after the prince to whom it was subject.

column1: gomadeścaiva candraś ca nāradau dundubhis tathā / somakaḥ mumanāścaiva vaibhrājaścaiva saptamaḥ //
column2: The several kingdoms were bounded by as many ranges of mountains, named severally Gomeda, Candra, Nārada, Dundubhi, Somaka, Sumanas, and Vaibhrāja.

column1: varṣācaleṣu ramyeṣu varṣeṣveteṣu cānaghāḥ / vasaṃti devagandharvasahitāḥ satataṃ prajāḥ // teṣu puṇyā janapadāścirācca mriyate janaḥ / nādhayo vyādhayo vāpi sarvakālasukhaṃ hi tat //
column2: In these mountains the sinless inhabitants ever dwell along with celestial spirits and gods in them are many holy places and the people there live for a long period, exempt from care and pain, and enjoying uninterrupted felicity.

column1: teṣāṃ nadyastu saptaiva varṣāṇāṃ ca samudragāḥ / nāmatastāḥ pravakṣyāmi śrutāḥ pāpaṃ haranti yāḥ // anutaptā śikhī caiva vipāśā tridivāklamaḥ / amṛtā sukṛtā caiva saptaitāstatra nimnagāḥ //
column2: There are also, in the seven divisions of Plakṣa, seven rivers, flowing to the sea, whose names alone are sufficient to take away sin they are the Anutaptā, Śikhī, Vipāsā, Tridivā, Kramu, Amritā, and Sukritā.

column1: ete śailās tathā nadyaḥ pradhānāḥ kathitāstava / kṣudraśailās tathā nadyastatra santi sahasraśaḥ / tāḥ pibandi sadāhṛṣṭā nadīrjanapadāstute //
column2: These are the chief rivers and mountains of Plakṣadvīpa, which I have enumerated to you but there are thousands of others of inferior magnitude.

column1: apasarpiṇī na teṣāṃ vai na caivotsarpiṇī dvija / na tvevāsti yugāvasthā teṣu stāneṣu saptasu // tretāyugasamaḥ kālaḥ sarvadaiva mahāmate / plakṣadvīpādiṣu brahmañ śākadvīpāntikeṣu vai //
column2: The people who drink of the waters of those rivers are always contented and happy, and there is neither decrease nor increase amongst them, neither are the revolutions of the four ages known in these Varṣas the character of the time is there uniformly that of the Treta or silver age.

column1: pañca varṣasahasrāṇi janā jīvantyanāmayāḥ / dharmaḥ pañcasvathaiteṣu varṇāśramavibhāgaśaḥ //
column2: In the five Dvīpas, worthy Brahman, from Plakṣa to Śāka, the length of life is five thousand years, and religious merit is divided amongst the several castes and orders of the people.

column1: āryakāḥ kurāraścaiva vidiśyā bhāvinaśce te / viprakṣatrivaiśyāste śūdrāś ca munisattama //
column2: The castes are called Āryaka, Kuru, Vivāsa, and Bhāvī, corresponding severally with Brahman, Kṣetriya, Vaiśya, and Śūdra.

column1: jmabūvṛkṣapramāṇastu tanmadhye sumahāṃstaruḥ / plakṣastannāmasaṃjñoyaṃ plakṣadvīpo dvijottama //
column2: In this Dvīpa is a large figtree F. religiosa, of similar size as the Jambutree of Jambudvīpa and this Dvīpa is called Plakṣa, after the name of the tree.

column1: ijyate tatra bhagavāṃstair varṇair āryakādibhiḥ / sīmarūpi jagatstraṣṭā sarvaḥ sarveśvaro hariḥ //
column2: Hari, who is all, and the creator of all, is worshipped in this continent in the form of Soma the moon.

column1: plakṣadvīpapramāṇena plakṣadvīpaḥ samāvṛtaḥ / tathaivekṣuramodena pariveṣānukāriṇā //
column2: Plakṣadvīpa is surrounded, as by a disc, by the sea of molasses, of the same extent as the land.

column1: ityevaṃ tava maitreya plakṣadvīpa udāhṛtaḥ / saṃkṣepeṇa mayā bhūyaḥ śālmalaṃ me nisāmaya //
column2: Such, Maitreya, is a brief description of Plakṣadvīpa.

column1: śālmamasyeśvaroḥvīro vapuṣmāṃstatsutāñchṛṇu / teṣāṃ tu nāmasaṃjñāni saptavarṣāṇi tāni vai //
column2: The hero Vapushmat was king of the next or Śālmaladvīpa, whose seven sons also gave designations to seven Varṣas, or divisions.

column1: śvetotha haritaścaiva jīmūto rohitas tathā / vaidyuto mānasaścaiva suprabhaś ca mahāmune //
column2: Their names were Śveta, Hārīta, Jīmūta, Rohita, Vaidyuta, Mānasa, and Suprabha.

column1: śālmalena samudrosau dvīpenekṣurasodakaḥ / vistāradviguṇenātha sarvataḥ saṃvṛtaḥ sthitaḥ //
column2: The Ikṣu sea is encompassed by the continent of Sālmala, which is twice its extent.

column1: tatrāpi parvatāḥ sapta vijñeyā ratnayonayaḥ / varṣābhivyañjakā ye tu tathā sapta ca nimnagāḥ //
column2: There are seven principal mountain ranges, abounding in precious gems, and dividing the Varṣas from each other and there are also seven chief rivers.

column1: kumudaścennataścaiva tṛtīyaś ca balāhakaḥ / droṇo yatra mahauṣadhyaḥ sa caturtho mahīdharaḥ //
column2: The mountains are called Kumuda, Unnata, Valāhaka, Drona, fertile in medicinal herbs, Kanka, Mahiṣa, and Kakkudwat.

column1: yonitoyo vitṛṣṇā ca candrā muktā vimocanī / nivṛttiḥ saptamī tāsāṃ smṛtāstāḥ pāpaśāntidāḥ //
column2: The rivers are Yaunī, Toyā, Vitṛṣṇā, Candrā, Śuklā, Vimocanī, and Nivritti all whose waters cleanse away sins.

column1: śālmale ye tu varṇāś ca vasantyete mahāmune / kapilāścāruṇāḥ pītāḥ kṛṣṇāścaiva pṛthak pṛthak // brahmaṇāḥ kṣatrayā vaiśyāḥ śudrāścaiva yajantitam / bhagavantaṃ samastasya viṣṇumātmānamavyayam / vāyubhūtaṃ makhaśreṣṭhair yajvano yajñasaṃsthitim //
column2: The Brahmans, Kṣetriyas, Vaiśyas, and Śūdras of this Dvīpa, called severally Kapilas, Arunas, Pītas, and Rohitas or tawny, purple, yellow, and red, worship the imperishable soul of all things, Viṣṇu, in the form of Vāyu wind, with pious rites, and enjoy frequent association with the gods.

column1: devānāmatra sānnadhyamatīva sumanohare / śālmaliḥ sumahānvṛkṣo nāmnā nirvṛtikārakaḥ //
column2: A large Śālmalī silkcotton tree grows in this Dvīpa, and gives it its name.

column1: eṣa dvīpaḥ samudreṇa surodena samāvṛtaḥ / vistārācchālmalasyaiva samena tu samantataḥ // surodakaḥ parivṛtaḥ kuśadvīpena sarvataḥ / śālmalasya tu vistarāddviguṇena samantataḥ //
column2: The Dvīpa is surrounded by the Surā sea sea of wine, of the same extent as itself. The Surā sea is entirely encircled by Kuśadvīpa, which is every way twice the size of the preceding continent.

column1: jyotiṣmataḥ kuśadvīpe sapta putrāñchṛṇuṣva tān // udbhido veṇumāṃścaiva veratho lambano dhṛtiḥ / prabhākarotikapilastannāmā varṣapaddhatiḥ //
column2: The king, Jyotishmat, had seven sons, Udbhida, Venumān, Swairatha, Lavana, Dhriti, Prabhākara, and Kapila, after whom the seven portions or Varṣas of the island were called Udbhida, &c.

column1: tasminvasanti manujāḥ saha daite yadānavaiḥ / tathaiva devagandharvayakṣakiṃpuruṣādayaḥ //
column2: There reside mankind along with Daityas and Dānavas, as well as with spirits of heaven and gods.

column1: varṇāstatrāpi catvāro nijānuṣṭhānatatparāḥ / daminaḥ śuṣmiṇaḥ snehā mandehāś ca mahāmune // brahmaṇāḥ kṣatriyā vaiśyāḥ śūdrāścānukramoditāḥ // yathoskakarmakartṛtvātsvādhikārokṣayāya te / tatraiva taṃ kuśadvīpe brahmarūpaṃ janārdanam / yajantaḥ kṣapayanty ugram adhikāraphalapradam //
column2: The four castes, assiduously devoted to their respective duties, are termed Dāmīs, Śushmis, Snehas, and Mandehas, who, in order to be relieved of the obligations imposed upon them in the discharge of their several functions, worship Janārddana, in the form of Brahmā, and thus get rid of the unpleasant duties which lead to temporal rewards.

column1: vidrumo hemaśailaś ca dyatimān puṣpavāṃs tathā / kuśaśayo hariścaiva saptamo mandarācalaḥ // varṣācalāstu saptaite tatra dvīpe mahāmune / nadyaś ca sapta tāsāṃ tu śṛṇu nāmānyanukramāt // dhūtapāpā śivā caiva pavitrā saṃmatis tathā / vidyudambhā mahī cānyā sarvapāpa harāstvimāḥ //
column2: The seven principal mountains in this Dvīpa are named Vidruma, Hemaśaila, Dyutimān, Puṣpavān, Kuśeśaya, Hari, and Mandara and the seven rivers are Dhūtapāpā, Śiva, Pavitrā, Sammati, Vidyudambhā, Mahhvanyā, Sarvapāpaharā besides these, there are numerous rivers and mountains of less importance.

column1: anyāḥ sahasraśastatra kṣudranadyastathācalāḥ / kuśadvīpe guśastambaḥ saṃjñayā tasya tatsmṛtam //
column2: Kuśadvīpa is so named from a clump of Kuśa grass Poa growing there.

column1: tatpramāṇena sa dvīpo ghṛtodena samāvṛtaḥ / ghṛtodaś ca samudro vai krauñcadvīpena saṃvṛtaḥ //
column2: It is surrounded by the Ghrita sea the sea of butter, of the same size as the continent.

column1: krauñcadvīpe dyutimataḥ putrāstasya mahātmanaḥ / tannāmāni ca varṣāṇi teṣāṃ cakre mahīpatiḥ // kuśalo mallagaścoṣṇaḥ pīvarothāndhakārakaḥ / muniś ca dundubhiścaiva saptaite tatsutā mune //
column2: The sea of Ghrita is encompassed by Kraunchadvīpa, which is twice as large as Kuśadvīpa. The king of this Dvīpa was Dyutimān, whose sons, and the seven Varṣas named after them, were Kuśala, Mallaga, Uṣṇa, Pīvara, Andhakāraka, Muni, and Dundubhi.

column1: krauñcaś ca vāmanaścaiva tṛtīyaścāndhakārakaḥ / caturtho ratnaśailaś ca svāhinī hayasannibhaḥ // divāvṛtpañcamaścātra tathānyaḥ puṇḍarīkavān / dundubhiś ca mahāśailo dviguṇāsta parasparam / dvīpādvīpeṣu ye śailā yathā dvīpāni te tathā //
column2: The seven boundary mountains, pleasing to gods and celestial spirits, are Krauncha, Vāmana, Andhakāraka, Devavrit, Puṇḍarīkavān, Dundubhi, and Mahaśaila each of which is in succession twice as lofty as the series that precedes it, in the same manner as each Dvīpa is twice as extensive as the one before it.

column1: varṣeṣveteṣu ramyeṣu tathā śailavareṣu ca / nivasaṃti nirātaṅkāḥ saha devagaṇaiḥ prajāḥ //
column2: The inhabitants reside there without apprehension, associating with the bands of divinities.

column1: puṣkarāḥ puṣkalā dhanyāstitikhyāś ca mahāmune / brahmaṇāḥ kṣatriyā vaiśyāḥ śudrāścānukramoditāḥ //
column2: The Brahmans are called Puṣkaras the Kṣetriyas, Puṣkalas the Vaiśyas are termed Dhanyas and the Śūdras, Tiṣyas.

column1: gaurī kumudvatī caiva sandhyā rātrirmanojavā / kṣāntiś ca puṇḍarīkā ca saptaitā varṣanimnagāḥ //
column2: They drink of countless streams, of which the principal are denominated Gaurī, Kumudvatī, Sandhyā, Rātri, Manojavā, Kṣānti, and Puṇḍarīkā.

column1: tatrāpi viṣṇurbhagavānpuṣkārādyair jānārdanaḥ / yāgau rudrasvarūpaś ca ijyate yajñasannidhau //
column2: The divine Viṣṇu, the protector of mankind, is worshipped there by the people, with holy rites, in the form of Rudra.

column1: dadhimaṇḍodakaścāpi śākadvīpena saṃvṛtaḥ / krauñcadvīpasya vistārāddviguṇena mahāmune //
column2: Krauncha is surrounded by the sea of curds, of a similar extent and that again is encompassed by Śākadvīpa.

column1: jaladaś ca kumāraś ca mukumāro marīcakaḥ / kusumodaś ca maudākiḥ saptamaś ca mahādrumaḥ //
column2: The sons of Bhavya, the king of Śākadvīpa, after whom its Varṣas were denominated, were Jalada, Kumāra, Sukumāra, Manīcaka, Kusumoda, Maudākī, and Mahādruma.

column1: pūrvastatrodayagirirjalādhārastathāparaḥ / tathā raivatakaḥ śyāmastathaivāstagirirdvija / āmbikeyas tathā ramyaḥ kesarī parvatottamaḥ //
column2: The seven mountains separating the countries were Udayagiri, Jalādhāra, Raivataka, Śyāma, Āmbikeya, Ramya, and Keśarī.

column1: śākastatra mahāvṛkṣaḥ siddhagandharvasevitaḥ / yatratyavātasaṃspārśādāhlādo jāyate paraḥ //
column2: There grows a large Sāka Teak tree, frequented by the Siddhas and Gandharvas, the wind from which, as produced by its fluttering leaves, diffuses delight.

column1: tatra puṇyā janapadāścāturvarṇyasamanvitāḥ / nadyaścātra mahāpuṇyāḥ sarvapāpabhayāpahāḥ //
column2: The sacred lands of this continent are peopled by the four castes.

column1: sukumārī kumārī ca nalinī dhenukā ca yā / ikṣuś ca veṇukā caiva gabhastī saptamī tathā //
column2: Its seven holy rivers, that wash away all sin, are the Sukumārī, Kumārī, Nalinī, Dhenukā, Ikṣu, Venukā, and Gabhastī.

column1: anyāś ca śataśastatra kṣudranadyo mahāmune / mahīdharās tathā santi śataśotha sahasraśaḥ // tāḥ pibanti mudāyuktā jaladādiṣu ye sthitāḥ / varṣaṣu te janapadāḥ svargādabhyetya medinīm //
column2: There are also hundreds and thousands of minor streams and mountains in this Dvīpa and the inhabitants of Jalada and the other divisions drink of those waters with pleasure, after they have returned to earth from Indras heaven.

column1: dharmahānirna teṣvasti na saṃgharṣaḥ parasparam / maryādāvyutkramo nāpi teṣu deśeṣu saptasu //
column2: In those seven districts there is no dereliction of virtue there is no contention there is no deviation from rectitude.

column2: I have thus described to you the orb of the earth the regions below its surface, or Pātālas and the Narakas, or hells and have briefly enumerated its oceans, mountains, continents, regions, and rivers what else do you wish to hear? Extent and situation of the seven spheres, viz.

column2: PARĀŚARA.

column2: The sphere of the earth or Bhūrloka, comprehending its oceans, mountains, and rivers, extends as far as it is illuminated by the rays of the sun and moon and to the same extent, both in diameter and circumference, the sphere of the sky Bhuvarloka spreads above it as far upwards as to the planetary sphere, or Swarloka.

column2: The planet Budha Mercury is two hundred thousand leagues above the lunar mansions. Śukra Venus is at the same distance from Mercury.

column1: aṅgarakopi śukrasya tatpramāṇe vyavasthitaḥ / lakṣadvaye tu bhaumasya sthito devapurohitaḥ // saurirbṛhaspateścordhvaṃ dvilakṣe samavasthitaḥ / saptarṣimaṇḍalaṃ tasmāllakṣamekaṃ dvijottamā // ṛṣibhyastu sahasrāṇāṃ śatādūrdhvaṃ vyavasthitaḥ / meḍhībhūtaḥ samastasya jyotiścakrasya vai dhruvaḥ //
column2: Aṅgāraka Mars is as far above Venus and the priest of the gods Vrihaspati, or Jupiter as far from Mars whilst Saturn Sani is two hundred and fifty thousand leagues beyond Jupiter. The sphere of the seven Ṛṣis Ursa Major is a hundred thousand leagues above Saturn and at a similar height above the seven Ṛṣis is Dhruva the polestar, the pivot or axis of the whole planetary circle.

column1: trailokyametatkathitamutsedhena mahāmune / ijyāphalasya bhūreṣā ijyā cātra pratiṣṭhitā //
column2: Such, Maitreya, is the elevation of the three spheres Bhūr, Bhuvar, Swar which form the region of the consequences of works.

column2: Above Dhruva, at the distance of ton million leagues, lies the sphere of saints, or Maharloka, the inhabitants of which dwell in it throughout a Kalpa, or day of Brahmā.

column2: At twice that distance is situated Janaloka, where Sanandana and other pureminded sons of Brahmā, reside.

column1: caturgaṇottare cordhvaṃ janalokāttapaḥ sthitaḥ / vairājā yatra te devāḥ sthitā dāhavivarjitāḥ //
column2: At four times the distance, between the two last, lies the Tapoloka the sphere of penance, inhabited by the deities called Vaibhrājas, who are unconsumable by fire.

column1: ṣaḍguṇenatapolokānsatyaloko virājate / apunarmārakā yatra brahmaloko hi saṃsmṛtaḥ //
column2: At six times the distance or twelve Crores, a hundred and twenty millions of leagues is situated Satyaloka, the sphere of truth, the inhabitants of which never again know death.

column1: etadaṇḍakaṭāhena tiryak codhvamadhas tathā / kapitthasya yathā bījaṃ sarvato vai samāvṛtam //
column2: The world is encompassed on every side and above and below by the shell of the egg of Brahmā, in the same manner as the seed of the woodapple is invested by its rind.

column1: daśottareṇa payasā maitreyāṇḍaṃ ca tadvṛtam / sarvombuparidhānosau vahninā veṣṭito bahiḥ //

column1: vahniś ca vāyunā vāyurmaitreya nabhasā vṛtaḥ / bhūtādinā nabhaḥ so 'pi mahatā pariveṣṭitaḥ / deśottarāmyaśeṣāṇi maitreyaitāni sapta vai // mahāntaṃ ca samāvṛtya pradhānaṃ samavasthitam / anantasya na tasyāntaḥ saṃkhyānaṃ cāpi vidyate // tadanantam asaṃkhyātapramāṇaṃ cāpi vai yataḥ / hetubhūtamaśeṣasya prakṛtiḥ sā parā mune // aṇḍānāṃ tu sahasrāṇāṃ sahasrāṇyayutāni ca / īdṛśānāṃ tathā tatra koṭikoṭiśatāni ca //
column2: The waters, again, are encompassed exteriorly by fire fire by air and air by Mind Mind by the origin of the elements Ahaṅkāra and that by Intellect each of these extends ten times the breadth of that which it encloses and the last is encircled by the chief Principle, Pradhāna, which is infinite, and its extent cannot be enumerated it is therefore called the boundless and illimitable cause of all existing things, supreme nature, or Prakriti the cause of all mundane eggs, of which there are thousands and tens of thousands, and millions and thousands of millions, such as has been described.

column1: hāruṇyagniryathā tailaṃ tile tadvatpumānapi / pradhāne 'vasthito vyāpī cetanātmātmavedanaḥ //
column2: Within Pradhāna resides Soul, diffusive, conscious, and selfirradiating, as fire is inherent in flint, or sesamum oil in its seed.

column1: pradhānaṃ ca pumāṃścaiva sarvabhūtātmabhūtayā / viṣṇuśaktyā mahābuddhe vṛtau saṃśrayadharmiṇau // tayoḥ saiva pṛthagbhāvakāraṇaṃ saṃśrayasya ca / kṣobhakāraṇabhūtā ca sargakāle mahāmate //
column2: Nature Pradhāna and soul Pumān are both of the character of dependants, and are encompassed by the energy of Viṣṇu, which is one with the soul of the world, and which is the cause of the separation of those two soul and nature at the period of dissolution of their aggregation in the continuance of things and of their combination at the season of creation.

column1: yathā saktaṃ jale vāto bibharti kaṇikāśatam / śaktiḥ sāpi tathā viṣṇoḥ pradhānapuruṣātmakam //
column2: In the same manner as the wind ruffles the surface of the water in a hundred bubbles, which of themselves are inert, so the energy of Viṣṇu influences the world, consisting of inert nature and soul.

column1: yathā ca pādayaur mūlaskandhaśākhādisaṃyutaḥ / ādibījātprabhavati bījānyanyāni vai tataḥ // prabhāvantitatastebhyaḥ sambhavantyapare drumāḥ / tepi tallakṣaṇadravyakāraṇānugatā mune // evamavyākṛtātpūrvaṃ jāyante mahadādayaḥ / viśaṃṣāntā statastebhyaḥ saṃbhavantyasurādayaḥ / tebhyaś ca putrāsteṣāṃ ca putrāṇāmapare sutāḥ //
column2: Again, as a tree, consisting of root, stem, and branches, springs from a primitive seed, and produces other seeds, whence grow other trees analogous to the first in species, product, and origin, so from the first unexpanded germ of nature, or Pradhāna spring Mahat Intellect and the other rudiments of things from them proceed the grosser elements and from them men and gods, who are succeeded by sons and the sons of sons.

column1: bījādvṛkṣapraroheṇa yathā nāpacayastaroḥ / bhūtānāṃ bhūtasargeṇa naivāstyapacayas tathā //
column2: In the growth of a tree from the seed, no detriment occurs to the parent plant, neither is there any waste of beings by the generation of others.

column1: sannidhānādyathākāśakālādyāḥ kāraṇaṃ taroḥ / tathaivāpariṇāmeva viśvasya bhagavānhariḥ //
column2: In like manner as space and time and the rest are the cause of the tree through the materiality of the seed, so the divine Hari is the cause of all things by successive developements through the materiality of nature.

column1: vrīhibīje yathā mūlaṃ nālaṃ patrāṅkurau tathā / kāṇḍakoṣastu puṣpaṃ ca kṣīraṃ tadvacca taṇjulāḥ // tuṣāḥ kaṇāś ca santo vai yāntyāvirbhāvamātmanaḥ / prarohahetusāmagryamāsādya munisattama // tathā karmasvanekeṣu devādyāḥ samavasthitāḥ / viṣṇuśaktiṃ samāsādya prarohamupayānti vai //
column2: As all the parts of the future plant, existing in the seed of rice, or the root, the culm, the leaf, the shoot, the stem, the bud, the fruit, the milk, the grain, the chaff, the ear, spontaneously evolve when they are in approximation with the subsidiary means of growth or earth and water, so gods, men, and other beings, involved in many actions or necessarily existing in those states which are the consequences of good or evil acts, become manifested only in their full growth, through the influence of the energy of Viṣṇu.

column1: sa ca viṣṇuḥ paraṃ brahma yataḥ sarvamidaṃ jagat / jagacca yo yatra cedaṃ yasmiṃś ca layameṣyati //
column2: This Viṣṇu is the supreme spirit Brahma, from whence all this world proceeds, who is the world, by whom the world subsists, and in whom it will be resolved.

column1: tadbrahma tatparaṃ dhāma sadasatparamaṃ padam / yasya sarvamabhedena yataścaitaccarācaram //
column2: That spirit or Brahma is the supreme state of Viṣṇu, which is the essence of all that is visible or invisible with which all that is, is identical and whence all animate and inanimate existence is derived.

column1: sa eva mūla prakṛtirvyaktarūpī jagacca saḥ / tasminneva layaṃ sarvaṃ yāti tatra ca tiṣṭhati //
column2: He is primary nature he, in a perceptible form, is the world and in him all finally melts through him all things endure.

column1: kattā kriyāṇāṃ sa ca ijyate kratuḥ sa evatatkarmaphalaṃ ca tasya / strugādiyatsādhanamapyaśeṣaṃ harerna kiñcivdyatiriktamasti //
column2: He is the performer of the rites of devotion he is the rite he is the fruit which it bestows he is the implements by which it is performed. There is nothing besides the illimitable Hari.

column2: Length of day and night.

column2: Having thus described to you the system of the world in general, I will now explain to you the dimensions and situations of the sun and other luminaries.

column2: The chariot of the sun is nine thousand leagues in length, and the pole is of twice that longitude the axle is fifteen millions and seven hundred thousand leagues long on which is fixed a wheel with three naves, five spokes, and six peripheries, consisting of the everduring year the whole constituting the circle or wheel of time.

column1: catvāriṃśatsahasrāṇi dvitīyo 'kṣo vivasvataḥ / pañcānyāni tu sārdhāni syandanasya mahāmate //
column2: The chariot has another axle, which is fortyfive thousand five hundred leagues long.

column1: ākṣapramāṇamubhayoḥ pramāṇaṃ tadyugārdhayo / hrasvokṣastadyugārdhena dhruvādhāro rathasya vai / dvitīyekṣe tu taccakraṃ sasthitaṃ mānasācale //
column2: The two halves of the yoke are of the same length respectively as the two axles the longer and the shorter. The short axle, with the short yoke, are supported by the polestar the end of the longer axle, to which the wheel of the car is attached, moves on the Mānasa mountain.

column1: mānasottaraśailasya pūrvato vāsavī purī / dakṣiṇe tu yama syānyāpratīcyāṃ varuṇasya ca / uttareṇa ca somasya tāsāṃ nāmāni me śṛṇu // vasvaukasārā śakrasya yāmyā saṃyamanī tathā / purī sukhājaleśasya somasya ca vibhāvarī //

column1: kāṣṭhāṃ gato dakṣiṇataḥ kṣipteṣuriva sarpati / maitreya bhagavānbhānurjyotiṣāṃ cakrasaṃyutaḥ //
column2: The glorious sun, Maitreya, darts like an arrow on his southern course, attended by the constellations of the Zodiac.

column1: ahorātravyavasthānakāraṇaṃ bhagavānraviḥ / devayānaḥ paraḥ panthā yogināṃ kleśasaṃkṣaye //
column2: He causes the difference between day and night, and is the divine vehicle and path of the sages who have overcome the inflictions of the world.

column1: divasasya varirmadhye sarvākālaṃ vyavasthitaḥ / sarvadvīpeṣu maitreya niśārdhasya ca sanmukhaḥ // udayāstamane caiva sarvakālaṃ tu saṃmukhe / vidiśāsu tvaśeṣāsu tathā brahman diśāsu ca //
column2: Whilst the sun, who is the discriminator of all hours, shines in one continent in midday, in the opposite Dvīpas, Maitreya, it will be midnight rising and setting are at all seasons, and are always relatively opposed in the different cardinal and intermediate points of the horizon.

column1: yair yatra dṛśyate bhāsvānsa teṣāmudayaḥ smṛtaḥ / tirobhāvaṃ ca yatraiti tatraivāstamanaṃ raveḥ //
column2: When the sun becomes visible to any people, to them he is said to rise when he disappears from their view, that is called his setting.
